column1: Hoboken ( HOH-boh-kən; Unami: Hupokàn) is a city in Hudson County
column2: New Jersey
column3: United States. As of the 2010 United States Census
column4: the city's population was 50
column6: having grown by 11
column8: 577 counted in the 2000 Census
column9: which had in turn increased by 5
column11: 397 in the 1990 Census. Hoboken is part of the New York metropolitan area and is the site of Hoboken Terminal
column12: a major transportation hub for the tri-state region.

column1: Hoboken was first settled as part of the Pavonia
column2: New Netherland colony in the 17th century. During the early 19th century the city was developed by Colonel John Stevens
column3: first as a resort and later as a residential neighborhood. Originally part of Bergen Township and later North Bergen Township
column4: it became a separate township in 1849 and was incorporated as a city in 1855. Hoboken is the location of the first recorded game of baseball and of the Stevens Institute of Technology
column5: one of the oldest technological universities in the United States. It is also known as the birthplace and hometown of Frank Sinatra; various streets and parks in the city have been named after him.

column2: the city was an integral part of the Port of New York and New Jersey and home to major industries for most of the 20th century. The character of the city has changed from a blue collar town to one of upscale shops and condominiums. It has been ranked 2nd in Niche's "2019 Best Places to Live in Hudson County" list.

column1: The name "Hoboken" was chosen by Colonel John Stevens when he bought land
column2: on a part of which the city still sits. The Lenape (later called Delaware Indian) tribe of Native Americans referred to the area as the "land of the tobacco pipe"
column3: most likely to refer to the soapstone collected there to carve tobacco pipes
column4: and used a phrase that became "Hopoghan Hackingh". Like Weehawken
column5: its neighbor to the north
column6: Communipaw and Harsimus to the south
column7: Hoboken had many variations in the folks-tongue. Hoebuck
column8: old Dutch for high bluff and likely referring to Castle Point (the district of the city highest above sea level)
column9: was used during the colonial era and later spelled as Hobuck
column10: Hobock
column11: Hobuk and Hoboocken. However
column13: the name was changed to Hoboken
column14: influenced by Flemish Dutch immigrants and a folk etymology had emerged linking the town of Hoboken to the similarly-named Hoboken district of Antwerp.Today
column15: Hoboken's unofficial nickname is the "Mile Square City"
column16: but it actually covers about 1.25 square miles (3.2 km2) of land and an area of 2 square miles (5.2 km2) when including the under-water parts in the Hudson River. During the late 19th/early 20th century the population and culture of Hoboken was dominated by German language speakers who sometimes called it "Little Bremen"
column17: many of whom are buried in Hoboken Cemetery

column1: Hoboken was originally an island which was surrounded by the Hudson River on the east and tidal lands at the foot of the New Jersey Palisades on the west. It was a seasonal campsite in the territory of the Hackensack
column2: a phratry of the Lenni Lenape
column3: who used the serpentine rock found there to carve pipes.

column1: The first recorded European to lay claim to the area was Henry Hudson
column2: an Englishman sailing for the Dutch East India Company
column3: who anchored his ship the Halve Maen (Half Moon) at Weehawken Cove on October 2
column4: 1609. Soon after it became part of the province of New Netherland.

column2: Michael Reyniersz Pauw
column3: a burgemeester (mayor) of Amsterdam and a director of the Dutch West India Company
column4: received a land grant as patroon on the condition that he would plant a colony of not fewer than fifty persons within four years on the west bank of what had been named the North River. Three Lenape sold the land that was to become Hoboken (and part of Jersey City) for 80 fathoms (146 m) of wampum
column5: 20 fathoms (37 m) of cloth
column6: 12 kettles
column7: six guns
column8: two blankets
column9: one double kettle and half a barrel of beer. These transactions
column10: variously dated as July 12
column11: 1630 and November 22
column13: represent the earliest known conveyance for the area. Pauw (whose Latinized name is Pavonia) failed to settle the land
column14: and he was obliged to sell his holdings back to the company in 1633.

column1: It was later acquired by Hendrick Van Vorst

column3: a farmer. In 1643
column4: north of what would be later known as Castle Point

column6: North America's first. In series of Indian and Dutch raids and reprisals

column18: the land came into the possession of William Bayard

column1: The first officially recorded game of baseball took place in Hoboken in 1846 between Knickerbocker Club and New York Nine at Elysian Fields. In 1845
column2: the Knickerbocker Club
column3: which had been founded by Alexander Cartwright
column4: began using Elysian Fields to play baseball due to the lack of suitable grounds on Manhattan. Team members included players of the St George's Cricket Club
column5: the brothers Harry and George Wright
column6: and Henry Chadwick
column7: the English-born journalist who coined the term "America's Pastime".

column2: several Manhattan-based members of the National Association of Base Ball Players were using the grounds as their home field while St. George's continued to organize international matches between Canada
column3: England and the United States at the same venue. In 1859
column4: George Parr's All England Eleven of professional cricketers played the United States XXII at Hoboken
column5: easily defeating the local competition. Sam Wright and his sons Harry and George Wright played on the defeated United States team
column6: a loss which inadvertently encouraged local players to take up baseball. Henry Chadwick believed that baseball and not cricket should become the national pastime after the game drawing the conclusion that amateur American players did not have the leisure time required to develop cricket skills to the high technical level required of professional players. Harry Wright and George Wright then became two of the first professional baseball players in the United States when Aaron Champion raised funds to found the Cincinnati Red Stockings in 1869.

column1: In 1865 the grounds hosted a championship match between the Mutual Club of New York City and the Atlantic Club of Brooklyn that was attended by an estimated 20
column2: 000 fans and captured in the Currier & Ives lithograph "The American National Game of Base Ball".With the construction of two significant baseball parks enclosed by fences in Brooklyn
column3: enabling promoters there to charge admission to games
column4: the prominence of Elysian Fields diminished.  In 1868 the leading Manhattan club
column5: Mutual
column6: shifted its home games to the Union Grounds in Brooklyn.  In 1880
column7: the founders of the New York Metropolitans and New York Giants finally succeeded in siting a ballpark in Manhattan that became known as the Polo Grounds.

column1: Few nonwhites had settled in Hoboken by 1901. The Brooklyn Eagle claimed that an unwritten sundown town policy prevented African Americans from residing or working there.
When the U.S. entered World War I
column2: the Hamburg-American Line piers in Hoboken (and New Orleans) were taken under eminent domain. Federal control of the port and anti-German sentiment led to part of the city being placed under martial law
column3: and many German immigrants were forcibly moved to Ellis Island or left the city of their own accord. Hoboken became the major point of embarkation and more than three million soldiers
column4: known as "doughboys"
column5: passed through the city. Their hope for an early return led to General Pershing's slogan
column6: "Heaven
column7: Hell or Hoboken... by Christmas."Following the war
column8: Italians
column9: mostly stemming from the Adriatic port city of Molfetta
column10: became the city's major ethnic group
column11: with the Irish also having a strong presence. While the city experienced the Great Depression
column12: jobs in the ships yards and factories were still available
column13: and the tenements were full. Middle-European Jews
column15: also made their way to the city and established small businesses. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
column18: oversaw the development of the Holland Tunnel (completed in 1927) and the Lincoln Tunnel (in 1937)
column19: allowing for easier vehicular travel between New Jersey and New York City

column1: The war facilitated economic growth in Hoboken
column2: as the many industries located in the city were crucial to the war effort. As men went off to battle
column3: more women were hired in the factories
column4: some (most notably
column5: Todd Shipyards)
column6: offering classes and other incentives to them. Though some returning service men took advantage of GI housing bills
column7: many with strong ethnic and familial ties chose to stay in town. During the 1950s
column8: the economy was still driven by Todd Shipyards
column9: Maxwell House
column10: Lipton Tea
column11: Hostess and Bethlehem Steel and companies with big plants were still not inclined to invest in huge infrastructure elsewhere. Unions were powerful and the pay was good.

column2: though
column3: things began to deteriorate: turn-of-the century housing started to look shabby and feel crowded
column4: shipbuilding was cheaper overseas
column5: and single-story plants surrounded by parking lots made manufacturing and distribution more economical than old brick buildings on congested urban streets. The city appeared to be in the throes of inexorable decline as industries sought (what had been) greener pastures
column6: port operations shifted to larger facilities on Newark Bay
column7: and the car
column8: truck and plane displaced the railroad and ship as the transportation modes of choice in the United States. Many Hobokenites headed to the suburbs
column9: often the close by ones in Bergen and Passaic Counties
column10: and real-estate values declined. Hoboken sank from its earlier incarnation as a lively port town into a rundown condition and was often included in lists with other New Jersey cities experiencing the same phenomenon
column11: such as Paterson
column14: and neighboring Jersey City.The old economic underpinnings were gone and nothing new seemed to be on the horizon. Attempts were made to stabilize the population by demolishing the so-called slums along River Street and build subsidized middle-income housing at Marineview Plaza
column16: at Church Towers. Heaps of long uncollected garbage and roving packs of semi-wild dogs were not uncommon sights. Though the city had seen better days
column17: Hoboken was never abandoned. New infusions of immigrants
column19: kept the storefronts open with small businesses and housing stock from being abandoned
column20: but there wasn't much work to be had. Washington Street
column23: and the tight-knit neighborhoods remained home to many who were still proud of their city. Stevens remained a premier technology school
column25: and Bethlehem Steel still housed sailors who were dry-docked on its piers. Italian-Americans and other came back to the "old neighborhood" to shop for delicatessen.In 1975
column26: the western part of the Keuffel and Esser Manufacturing Complex (known as "Clock Towers") was converted into residential apartments
column28: engineering and drafting facility from 1907 to 1968; the eastern part portion became residential apartments in 1984 (now called the  Grand Adams).

column1: The Hudson Waterfront defined Hoboken as an archetypal port town and powered its economy from the mid-19th to mid-20th century
column2: by which time it had become essentially industrial (and mostly inaccessible to the general public). The large production plants of Lipton Tea and Maxwell House
column3: and the drydocks of Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation and Todd Shipbuilding dominated the northern portion for many years. On June 30
column5: a large fire at the Norddeutscher Lloyd piers killed numerous people and caused almost $10 million in damage. The southern portion (which had been a U.S. base of the Hamburg-American Line) was seized by the federal government under eminent domain at the outbreak of World War I
column6: after which it became (with the rest of the Hudson County) a major East Coast cargo-shipping port.

column1: With the development of the Interstate Highway System and containerization shipping facilities (particularly at Port Newark-Elizabeth Marine Terminal)
column2: the docks became obsolete
column3: and by the 1970s were more or less abandoned. A large swath of River Street

column11: sometimes absurd politics and court cases. By the 1990s

column18: Hurricane Sandy caused widespread flooding in Hoboken
column20: 700 homes flooded and causing $100 million in damage after the storm "filled up Hoboken like a bathtub". Workers in Hoboken had the highest rate of public transportation use in the nation
column21: with 56% commuting daily via mass transit. Hurricane Sandy caused seawater to flood half the city
column22: crippling the PATH station at Hoboken Terminal when more than 10 million gallons of water dumped into the system. In December 2013 Mayor Dawn Zimmer testified before a U.S. Senate Committee on the impact the storm had on Hoboken's businesses and residents

The $90 million park features many environmentally friendly features and includes an underground stormwater detention system that can store roughly one million gallons of water to help mitigate flooding. The project is expected to be completed sometime in 2022.A 2014 renovation to the 14th Street Viaduct near the city's northwest edge saw the creation of several recreational areas underneath the structure that include a dog park
column20: and street hockey and basketball courts amid a new cobblestone streetscape.The Hudson River Waterfront Walkway is a state-mandated master plan to connect the municipalities from the Bayonne Bridge to the George Washington Bridge creating an 18-mile (29 km)-long urban linear park and provide contiguous unhindered access to the water's edge. By law
column21: any development on the waterfront must provide a public promenade with a minimum width of 30 feet (9.1 m). To date

column24: the promenade and bike path from Newark to 5th Streets
column30: and 14th Street north to southern side of Weehawken Cove. Other segments of river-front held privately are not required to build a walkway until the land is re-developed.

column1: The City of Hoboken is governed within the Faulkner Act (formally known as the Optional Municipal Charter Law) under the mayor-council (Plan D) system of municipal government
column2: implemented based on the recommendations of a Charter Study Commission as of January 1
column3: 1953. The city is one of 71 municipalities (of the 565) statewide that use this form of government. The governing body is comprised of the Mayor and the nine-member City Council. The city council is comprised of three members elected at-large from the city as a whole
column4: and six members who each represent one of the city's six wards. All of the members of the city council are elected to four-year terms of office in non-partisan elections on a staggered basis in odd-numbered years
column5: with the six ward seats up for election together and the three at-large and mayoral seats up for vote two years later.In July 2011
column6: the city council voted to move municipal elections from May to November. The first shifted election were held in November 2013
column7: with all officials elected in 2009 and 2011 having their terms extended by six months.As of 2020
column8: the mayor of Hoboken is Ravinder Bhalla
column9: whose term of office ends December 31
column10: 2021. Members of the city council are Council President Jennifer Giattino (2023; 6th Ward)
column11: Council Vice President Vanessa Falco (2021; at-large)
column17: Ruben J. Ramos Jr. (2023; 4th Ward) and Michael Russo (2023; 3rd Ward).In the 2017 general election
column18: Ravinder Bhalla was elected to succeed Dawn Zimmer becoming the state's first Sikh mayor; Zimmer had chosen not to run for re-election to a third term and had endorsed Bhalla for the post. Bhalla's running mates
column19: incumbents James Doyle and Emily Jabbour
column20: won two of the at-large seats
column21: while the third seat was won Vanessa Falco who had been aligned with the slate of mayoral candidate Michael DeFusco. Zimmer had been the city council president and first took office as mayor on July 31
column25: was arrested on allegations of corruption stemming from a decade-long FBI operation. Zimmer
column28: runoff election to Cammarano by 161 votes
column29: served as acting mayor until winning a special election to fill the remainder of the term on November 3
column30: 2009. She was sworn in as mayor on November 6 as is the first female mayor of Hoboken. Zimmer won re-election in November 2013 to a second term of office and began her second term in January 2014.

column1: The city is protected by the 132 paid firefighters of the city of Hoboken Fire Department (HFD). Established in 1891
column2: the HFD currently operates under the command of a Department Chief
column3: to whom two Deputy Chiefs report. The department reported to 3
column4: 352 emergency calls in 2010
column5: arriving in an average of 2.6 minutes from the time the original call was received. The HFD has been a Class 1 rated fire department since 1996 as determined by the Insurance Services Office
column6: one of only three in New Jersey
column7: joining Hackensack and Cherry Hill. HFD's firehouses
column8: including its fire museum
column9: are listed on the National Register of Historic Places.The department is part of the Metro USAR Strike Team
column10: which consists of nine North Jersey fire departments and other emergency services divisions working to address major emergency rescue situations.

the city had a total of 31.79 miles (51.16 km) of roadways

Two highway tunnels that connect New Jersey to New York are located close to Hoboken. The Lincoln Tunnel is north of the city in Weehawken. The Holland Tunnel is south of the city in downtown Jersey City.

column1: Hoboken has no airports. Airports which serve Hoboken are operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. These airports are Newark Liberty International Airport
